dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: You know, I think a lot of people assume CFOs are just number-crunchers, but they're actually a pretty solid leading indicator for the economy.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: You know, I think a lot of people assume CFOs are just number-crunchers, but they're actually a pretty solid leading indicator for the economy.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Many on Wall Street primarily use CFO sentiment as an indicator of the business environment, but deteriorating forecasts can sometimes help warn of looming market downturns, historical data shows.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, absolutely. Like this PwC survey shows 96% of them are bracing for a downturn—that's up from 88% last year. That's a huge jump in pessimism.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, absolutely. Like this PwC survey shows ninety six percent of them are bracing for a downturn-that's up from eighty eight percent last year. That's a huge jump in pessimism.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Recession fears are back in full force: 97% of CFOs said that an economic downturn has already begun or will begin in 2020up from 88% who said the same thing last year, according to Deloittes latest CFO Signals Survey.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and it's not just a one-off. Back in 2018, when optimism dropped, the S&P 500 took a nearly 7% hit soon after.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and it's not just a one-off. Back in twenty eighteen, when optimism dropped, the S&P five hundred took a nearly seven percent hit soon after.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: That statistic fell to 24% in the following quarter, right before the S&P 500 dropped almost 7% in May and again by nearly 6% from mid-July to August.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and then again in December that year—CFO optimism hit a two-year low right before the market shed over 9%.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and then again in December that year-C F O optimism hit a two-year low right before the market shed over nine percent.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Business optimism also notably declined before the big December 2018 market sell-off, when the S&P 500 shed over 9%: Over two thirds of CFOs warned that the U.S. market was overvalued, and a metric of their forward-looking optimism hit a two-year low.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It's kind of eerie how often their sentiment lines up with what happens next. Like before the 2007 crisis, pessimistic CFOs outnumbered optimists four to one.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's kind of eerie how often their sentiment lines up with what happens next. Like before the two thousand seven crisis, pessimistic CFOs outnumbered optimists four to one.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Going further back, CFO sentiment was also relatively accurate in warning of the 2008 financial crisis: According to Dukes CFO Global Business Outlook, optimism had plunged to a record low by September 2017with pessimistic CFOs outnumbering optimists by around four to one.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But Mark Peterson from Sterling Asset Management makes a good point—it's not just about sentiment alone. It's how that turns into actual behavior, like cutting costs or holding back on spending.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But Mark Peterson from Sterling Asset Management makes a good point-it's not just about sentiment alone. It's how that turns into actual behavior, like cutting costs or holding back on spending.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: While as a stand-alone they dont offer much insight, its most helpful to look at these surveys hand-in-hand with hard economic data, says Mark Freeman, chief investment officer at Socorro Asset Management.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And over 80% of CFOs have already taken defensive actions, which tells you they're not just worried—they're preparing.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And over eighty percent of CFOs have already taken defensive actions, which tells you they're not just worried-they're preparing.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: More than 80% of CFOs also said they had already taken at least one defensive action to mitigate against a potential downturn, as evidenced by their growing focus on cost reduction and returning cash.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And trade policy is still their biggest external worry, which makes sense given all the uncertainty lately.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And trade policy is still their biggest external worry, which makes sense given all the uncertainty lately.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Nearly two thirds of CFOs surveyed by Deloitte said that U.S. economic performance beyond 2020 will depend substantially on the outcome of the elections, while trade policy remains CFOs most worrisome external risk.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Plus, expectations for business spending hit a four-year low. That's a concrete sign things might slow down.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Plus, expectations for business spending hit a four-year low. That's a concrete sign things might slow down.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Respondents also cited falling expectations for two key measures of the economy: Consumer sentiment, which has largely held steady so far, and business spending, expectations for which hit a three-year low.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: So even though consumer sentiment has held up so far, if businesses pull back, it could ripple through everything.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So even though consumer sentiment has held up so far, if businesses pull back, it could ripple through everything.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Respondents also cited falling expectations for two key measures of the economy: Consumer sentiment, which has largely held steady so far, and business spending, expectations for which hit a three-year low.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: For sure. It's like the canary in the coal mine, but for corporate America.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure. It's like the canary in the coal mine, but for corporate America.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And with elections coming up, nearly two-thirds of CFOs think the economy depends heavily on the outcome. That adds another layer of unpredictability.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And with elections coming up, nearly two-thirds of CFOs think the economy depends heavily on the outcome. That adds another layer of unpredictability.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Nearly two thirds of CFOs surveyed by Deloitte said that U.S. economic performance beyond 2020 will depend substantially on the outcome of the elections, while trade policy remains CFOs most worrisome external risk.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's all interconnected. Sentiment, behavior, policy—it's a messy picture, but CFO surveys give us clues.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it's all interconnected. Sentiment, behavior, policy-it's a messy picture, but C F O surveys give us clues.
